page.title: Black Country Living Museum Pawnbrokers Shop

revision.comment: /* Pawnbroking in the Black Country */Cleanup/[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: a overview → an overview using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The Pawnbroker's Shop that has been reconstructed at [[Black Country Living Museum]] is one of a pair of cottages built in the 1840s, from School Lane in [[Himley]].
==Pawnbroking in the Black Country== {{coord|52|31|23.1|N|2|4|36.81|W|region:GB|display=title}}
For an overview of Pawnbroking please see [[Pawnbroking|The History of Pawnbroking]].
[[File:Pawnbrokers.JPG|thumb|Outside of pawnbrokers shop at Black Country Living Museum]]
Pawnshops prospered in areas where the wages were low and unstable. In the Black Country in 1870 there were 160 pawnbrokers in the area, [[Walsall]] had 15 and [[Wednesbury]] had 48. <ref> Wilkinson, John A. 'Pawnbroking in the Black Country'. Black Country Living Museum, 1991, p.15. </ref> For a housewife with a large family to look after it was a constant struggle to make ends meet. It was not uncommon for a family to have linen or clothes that they would pawn as a bridging loan until next payday. The struggling family could pawn their goods on a Monday and could buy them back the following Friday or Saturday. <ref> Wilkinson, John A. 'Pawnbroking in the Black Country'. Black Country Living Museum, 1991, p.15. </ref> The items pawned were taken as security for a loan, the value of the item was based on what the pawnbroker thought he would get if he sold the item on. In return the customer would receive the loan a ticket. To redeem their pledge the customer had to pay the loan back in full plus any charges this included the valuation of their items and the cost of the ticket.<ref>{{cite book|last=Black Country Living Museum|title=Black Country Living Museum|year=2012|publisher=Black Country Living Museum Trust|location=Dudley|isbn=978-0-9562031-2-0}}</ref>
Pawnbrokers in the Black Country needed to be where the people were. Some of these businesses started in [[Public Houses]], which were frequently visited and saved customers a trip into town. <ref> Wilkinson, John A. 'Pawnbroking in the Black Country'. Black Country Living Museum, 1991, p.16. </ref> Other Pawnbrokers operated out of converted houses in prominent positions like [[corner shops]].
==As a Museum Exhibit== [[File:Pawnbrokers Window.JPG|thumb|Window of pawnbrokers shop at Black Country Living Museum]]
The pair of cottages from School Lane in Himley originally operated as a corner shop. The setting of the display was designed to represent a small scale business. The shop takes its name from a well known Black Country pawnbroker, Joseph Wiltshire, who owned shops in [[Great Bridge, West Midlands|Great Bridge]], [[Wolverhampton]] and Carter's Green in [[West Bromwich]]. The exhibit at the Black Country Living Museum combines pawnbroking with retail, as did many pawnbroking businesses in the 19th century. In the museum's reconstruction the unredeemed goods and other stock are sold in the front room, while pawning of goods was done in the 'pledge room' at the back.<ref>{{cite book|last=Black Country Living Museum|title=Black Country Living Museum|year=2012|publisher=Black Country Living Museum Trust|location=Dudley|isbn=978-0-9562031-2-0}}</ref>
The shop window of the Pawnbroker's gives a good example of the types of goods that customers would 'pledge'. The display includes shoes, clothes, furs, musical instruments, children's toys and even a set of false teeth.
== References == {{reflist}} {{Black Country Living Museum}} [[Category:Black Country Living Museum]]

revision.comment: Space in title of <ref> is in original, so must remain. Please stop doing this.

revision.text:
'''COBRA''' (or '''CoBrA''') was a European [[avant-garde]] [[art movement|movement]] active from 1948 to 1951. The name was coined in 1948 by [[Christian Dotremont]] from the initials of the members' home cities: [[Copenhagen]] (Co), [[Brussels]] (Br), [[Amsterdam]] (A). ==History== During the time of occupation of World War II, the Netherlands had been disconnected from the art world beyond its borders. COBRA was formed shortly thereafter. This international movement of artists who worked experimentally evolved from the criticisms of Western society and a common desire to break away from existing art movements, including "detested" naturalism and "sterile" [[Abstraction (art)|abstraction]]. Experimentation was the symbol of an unfettered freedom, which, according to Constant, was ultimately embodied by children and the expressions of children.{{cite book |last1=Baumgartner |first1=Michael |title=Klee and Cobra: A Child's Play |publisher=Hatje Cantz |pages=59–60}} COBRA was formed by [[Karel Appel]], [[Constant Nieuwenhuys|Constant]], [[Guillaume Cornelis van Beverloo|Corneille]], [[Christian Dotremont]], [[Asger Jorn]], and [[Joseph Noiret]] on 8 November 1948 in the Café Notre-Dame, Paris,MOMA online [http://moma.org/collection/details.php?theme_id=10954&displayall=1 collections page] with the signing of a manifesto, "La cause était entendue" ("The Case Was Settled"),"La cause était entendue" is an ironical reference to the manifesto "[http://www.andrebreton.fr/Resources/Assets/56600100560650/HR_56600100560650_1.jpg La cause est entendue] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718110537/http://www.andrebreton.fr/Resources/Assets/56600100560650/HR_56600100560650_1.jpg |date=2011-07-18 }}" (The Case Is Settled) from the supporters of Revolutionary Surrealism drawn up by Dotremont.[http://brbl-dl.library.yale.edu/vufind/Record/3558757 ''La cause etait entendue'', first version of the CoBrA group's manifesto, 8 November 1948, Yale University Library, Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library] Formed with a unifying doctrine of complete freedom of colour and form, as well as antipathy towards [[Surrealism]], the artists also shared an interest in [[Marxism]] as well as modernism.
Their working method was based on spontaneity and experiment, and they drew their inspiration in particular from children’s drawings, from primitive art forms and from the work of [[Paul Klee]] and [[Joan Miró]].
Coming together as an amalgamation of the Dutch group Reflex, the Danish group Høst and the Belgian Revolutionary Surrealist Group, the group only lasted a few years but managed to achieve a number of objectives in that time: the periodical ''Cobra'', a series of collaborations between various members called ''Peintures-Mot'' and two large-scale exhibitions. The first of these was held at the [[Stedelijk Museum]] in Amsterdam, November 1949, the other at the [[Palais des Beaux-Arts]] in [[Liège (city)|Liège]] in 1951. In November 1949 the group officially changed its name to Internationale des Artistes Expérimentaux with membership having spread across Europe and the United States, although this name has never stuck. The movement was officially disbanded in 1951, but many of its members remained close, with Dotremont in particular continuing collaborations with many of the leading members of the group.{{cite web |title=CoBrA Museum |url=http://www.cobra-museum.nl/en/cobra.html |location=Cobra Museum, The Netherlands |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621043026/http://www.cobra-museum.nl/en/cobra.html |archivedate=2008-06-21 |df= }}. The primary focus of the group consisted of semi-abstract paintings with brilliant color, violent brushwork, and distorted human figures inspired by primitive and folk art and similar to American [[action painting]]. Cobra was a milestone in the development of [[Tachisme]] and European [[abstract expressionism]]. Cobra was perhaps the last avant-garde movement of the twentieth century.W. Stokvis – [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=h8HpAAAAMAAJ&q=COBRA+art+movement&dq=COBRA+art+movement&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAGoVChMIl-yRpr_dxgIVQ1wUCh24hQyn Cobra: The Last Avant-garde Movement of the Twentieth Century] Lund Humphries 2004, 349 pages, {{ISBN|0853318980}} [Retrieved 2015-07-15] According to Nathalie Aubert the group only lasted officially for three years (1948 to 1951). After that period each artist in the group developed their own individual paths.Auber, Nathalie. “’Cobra after Cobra’ And The Alba Congress: From Revolutionary Avant-Garde To Situationist Experiment.” Third Text 20.2 (2006): 259–267. Art Source. Web. 14 Sept. 2015. === Manifesto === The manifesto, entitled, "''La cause était entendue''" (The Case Was Settled) was written by CoBrA member Christian Dotremont and signed by all founding members in Paris in 1948. It was directly speaking to their experience attending the Centre International de Documentation sur l’Art d’Avant-garde in which they felt the atmosphere was sterile and authoritarian. It was a statement of working collaboratively in an organic mode of experimentation in order to develop their work separate from the current place of the avant-garde movement. The name of the manifesto was also a play on words from an earlier document signed by Belgian and French Revolutionary Surrealists in July 1947, entitled "La cause est entendue" (The Case Is Settled).{{cite book|last1=Stokvis|first1=Willemijn|title=Cobra: The Last Avant-Garde Movement|date=2004|publisher=Lund Humphries|location=Aldershot}} == Method == The European artists were different from their American counterparts (the [[Abstract expressionists]]) for they preferred the process over the product and introduced primitive, mythical, and folkloric elements along with a decorative input from their children.Cooke, Lynne. “Review.” The Burlington Magazine 126, no. 978 (September 1, 1984): 583. One of the new approaches that united the COBRA artists was their unrestrained use of strong colors, along with violent handwritings and figuration which can be either frightening or humorous. Their art was alive with subhuman figures in order to mirror the terror and weakness of our time unlike the dehumanized art of [[Abstraction]].Hoffmann, Edith. "Cobra Exhibition in Rotterdam." The Burlington Magazine 108.760 (1966): 388–89. JSTOR. Web. 14 Sept. 2015. This spontaneous method was a rejection of Renaissance art, specialization, and ‘civilized art’, they preferred ‘uncivilized’ forms of expression which created an interplay between the conscious and the unconscious instead of the [[Surrealist]] interest in the unconscious alone. The childlike in their method meant a pleasure in painting, in the materials, forms, and finally the picture itself; this aesthetic notion was called ‘desire unbound’. The Dutch Artists in particular within Cobra (Corneille, Appel, Constant) were interested in Children's art.“We Wanted to start again like a child” Karel Appel insisted.Karel Appel, from an interview with Eleanor Flomenhaft, October 16, 1975; cited in Flomenhaft 1985, p. 33. As part of the Western Left, they were built upon the fusion of Art and Life through experiment in order to unite form and expression. == CoBrA exhibitions == They exhibited mainly in Holland, but also Paris and other countries in Europe.{{cite journal |jstor= 875035|title=Cobra Exhibition in Rotterdam |date=July 1966 |journal=The Burlington Magazine |last = Hoffmann |first=Edith}} ===Stedelijk Museum Exhibition=== The first major exhibition was held at the [[Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam]] in November 1949 under the title "International Experimental Art". The museum's director and curator [[Willem Sandberg]] was interested in bringing experimentalism and abstraction to The Netherlands, and had also been an active member of the Dutch Resistance during the war. He was deeply involved with the CoBrA group and maintained direct contacts between the artists and the Stedelijk Museum.http://www.stedelijk.nl/en/exhibitions/cobra-the-stedelijkhttp://www.eyemagazine.com/feature/article/willem-sandberg-warm-printing The architect [[Aldo van Eyck]], who would later become known for his architecture of playgrounds as cultural critique, was asked to do the interior design of the exhibition. The close relationship between Van Eyck and the artists from the CoBrA, who also drew their inspiration in particular from children's drawings, makes it probable that much of Eyck's early inspiration for the playgrounds may have derived from CoBrA.http://stichtingconstant.nl/cobra-1948-1951http://merijnoudenampsen.org/2013/03/27/aldo-van-eyck-and-the-city-as-playground/ The Stedelijk Museum exhibition gave rise to furious criticism from press and the public. A critic from ''[[Het Vrije Volk]]'' (Free People) wrote, “Geklad, geklets en geklodder in het Stedelijk Museum” (“Smirch, twaddle and mess in the SMA"). The CoBrA artists are considered scribblers and [[con artists]]. Newspapers spoke of offensive art and provocation on the part of the artists, and one evening for experimental poetry at the Stedelijk was the occasion for a public brawl. === Exhibition in Liège === The last CoBrA exhibit was located in [[Liège]], Belgium, in 1951. Shortly after this exhibit, the group dissolved. The show was organised by [[Pierre Alechinsky]], an artist from Belgium. The Dutch architect, Van Eyck designed the exhibition layout, just as he had for the 1949 CoBrA exhibition in Stedelijk. The innovations of this exhibit were that the composition for the wall was in a grid formation. In addition, the sculptures, which were featured in this show were on coal beds from the Liege area itself. This show was not specific to only CoBrA artists, and also, major artists of the CoBrA movement were not in this exhibit due to the existing conflict within the group that eventually led to the collapse of CoBrA shortly after in the same year.{{Cite web |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=V-_iBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76&dq=cobra+1951+exhibition&source=bl&ots=NiAIA1neY2&sig=OHUBjMPfxSa5so9ttjvYmWZoVp4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CFcQ6AEwDGoVChMItfTTg4D6xwIVlo6SCh2MagKs#v=onepage&q=cobra%201951%20exhibition&f=false |title=The Art and Politics of Asger Jorn: The Avant-Garde Won't Give Up |date=August 2014 |accessdate= |website=Google Books |publisher=Ashgate Publishing Unlimited |last=Kurczynski |first=Karen}} === Group shows === * WestKunst (Cologne, 1981) * Paris-Paris (Paris, 1981) * Aftermath (London, 1981) * Two Survey shows (Hamburg, 1982; Paris and the French provinces also 1982) * The Spirit of Cobra (Fort Lauderdale, 2013) ==Participants== {{Div col}} *[[Karel Appel]] (1921–2006) *[[Pierre Alechinsky]] (born 1927) *[[Else Alfelt]] (1910–1974) *[[Jean-Michel Atlan]] (1913–1960) *[[Ejler Bille]] (1910–2004) *[[Pol Bury]] (1922–2005) *[[Jacques Calonne]] (born 1930) *[[Hugo Claus]] (1929–2008) *[[Corneille Guillaume Beverloo|Corneille]] (1922–2010) *[[:fr:Jacques Doucet (peintre)|Jacques Doucet]] (1924–1994) *[[Lotti van der Gaag]] (1923–1999) *[[William Gear]] (1915–1997) *[[Stephen Gilbert]] (1910–2007) *[[Svavar Guðnason]] (1909–1988) *[[Henry Heerup]] (1907–1993) *[[Edouard Jaguer]] (1924–2006) *[[Asger Jorn]] (1914–1973) *[[Aart Kemink]] (1914–2006) *[[Lucebert]] (1924–1994) *[[Ernest Mancoba]] (1904–2002) *[[Jørgen Nash]] (1920–2004) *[[Jan Nieuwenhuys]] (1922–1986) *[[Erik Ortvad]] (1917–2008) *[[Pieter Ouborg]] (1893–1956) *[[Carl-Henning Pedersen]] (1913–2007) *[[Bert Schierbeek]] (1918–1996) *[[Max Walter Svanberg]] (1912–1994) *[[Uno Vallman]] (1913–2004) *[[Serge Vandercam]] (1924–2005) *[[Sonja Ferlov Mancoba]] (1911–1984) {{Div col end}} ===Related artists=== Notable artists who had contact with, and/or were influenced by COBRA: {{Div col}} *[[Enrico Baj]] *[[Jerome Bech]] *[[James E. Brewton]] *[[Jacqueline de Jong]] *[[Freddy Flores Knistoff]] *[[Herbert Gentry]] *[[Robert Jacobsen]] *[[Jean Messagier]] *[[Vali Myers]] *[[John Olsen (Australian artist)|John Olsen]] *[[Gina Pellón]] (1926–2014) *[[Dana Schutz]]{{cite web|last1=Chin|first1=Mei|title=Dana Schutz (Interview)|url=http://bombmagazine.org/article/2799/dana-schutz|website=BOMB Magazine|accessdate=23 January 2017}} *[[Shinkichi Tajiri]] *[[Alasdair Grant Taylor|Alasdair Taylor]] *[[Louis Van Lint]] *[[Maurice Wyckaert]] (1923–1996) {{Div col end}} === Criticism === * [[Alison M. Gingeras]] praises Cobra as being a, "...wonderfully messy, cacophonous, and multi-tentacled," entity.[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/inside-cobra-the-wonderfully-messy-avant-garde-movement-youve-never-heard-of_55e49410e4b0aec9f3540ee4 "Revisiting The Radically Avant-Garde Movement Art History Forgot". ''The Huffington Post''. Retrieved 2015-09-22] * [[Ernest Mancoba]] (1904–2002), of South Africa, claimed to be one of the only black artists of Cobra. In his own words, Mancoba, a clear supporter of the Cobra movement, criticizes the views of his fellow artists regarding himself: "The embarrassment that my presence caused to the point of making me, in their eyes, some sort of 'Invisible Man' or merely the consort of a European woman artist—was understandable, as before me there had never been to my knowledge any black man taking part in the visual arts 'avant garde' of the Western World." ==Legacy== There is a Cobra Museum in [[Amstelveen]], Netherlands, displaying works by [[Karel Appel]] and other international avant-garde artists.[http://www.cobra-museum.nl/en/ Cobra Museum of Modern Art], Amstelveen The NSU Art Museum in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, is known for its large assemblage of works of CoBrA art. The museum displays works by Karel Appel, Pierre Alechinsky, and Asger Jorn, the movement's leading exponents. (www.nsuartmuseum.org ) Auctioneers Bruun Rasmussen held an auction of COBRA artists on April 3, 2006 in Copenhagen. It set records for the highest price for an [[Asger Jorn]] painting (6.4 million DKK for ''Tristesse Blanche'') and for the highest amount raised in a single auction in Denmark (30 million DKK in total). ==See also== * [[School of Paris]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|COBRA (movement)}} {{Wikiquote}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070114184219/http://www.didrichsenmuseum.fi/cobra/englanti/cobra_tietoa.html Didrichsenmuseum.fi] *[http://galeriebirch.dk/en/cobra/ Galerie Birch, Danish gallery founded 1946 specializing in COBRA] *[https://archive.is/20121204191947/http://www.museumjorn.dk/ Museum Jorn, Silkeborg] {{westernart}} {{Avant-garde}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cobra (Avant-Garde Movement)}} [[Category:Art Informel and Tachisme]] [[Category:Modern art]] [[Category:European artist groups and collectives]] [[Category:Art movements]] [[Category:School of Paris]] [[Category:Words coined in the 1940s]] [[Category:Acronyms]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox document |document_name=Declaration of Independence of Azerbaijan |image=Declaration of Independence of Azerbaijan.png |image_width=200px |image_caption=Original text of the Declaration in [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] |date_created=28 May 1918 |date_ratified= |location_of_document=[[National Museum of History of Azerbaijan]] |writer= |signers=[[Hasan bey Aghayev]], [[Fatali Khan Khoyski]], [[Nasib Yusifbeyli]], [[Jamo bey Hajinski]], Shafi bey Rustambeyli, [[Nariman bey Narimanbeyov]], [[Javad Malik-Yeganov]] and [[Mustafa Mahmudov]] |purpose=To announce the independence of Azerbaijan }}
The '''Declaration of Independence of Azerbaijan''' ({{lang-az|Azərbaycanın İstiqlal Bəyannaməsi}}) is the [[declaration of independence]] of the [[Azerbaijan Democratic Republic]] from the [[Russian Empire]]. Azerbaijan was proclaimed independent in [[Tiflis]] on 28 May 1918.<ref name="Элм">{{cite book|title=Азербайджанская Демократическая Республика (1918 - 1920)|year=1998|publisher=Элм|isbn=5-8066-0897-2|page=316}}</ref>
The Azerbaijan Democratic Republic was founded by the Azerbaijani National Council in Tiflis on May 28, 1918 after the collapse of the Russian Empire that began with the Russian Revolution of 1917. The Muslim representation in the defunct [[Transcaucasian Seim]] had constituted itself into the Azerbaijani National Council, and on May 28, 1918 proclaimed that a new nation was born. So far only a geographical reference, Azerbaijan now became the name of a state, and some 2 million people, called variously Tatars, Transcaucasian Muslims and Caucasian Turks, officially became Azerbaijanis.<ref name="Swietochowski"/>
== History == At the beginning of 1918, the political situation in the Caucasus remained critical. After the failure of the Russian-Germany peace talks in Brest-Litovsk, the German-Turkish troops began to attack on 6 December 1917 in the Caucasus. At the beginning of January 1918 Turkish troops were able to capture the Kars and Batumi provinces.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archives.gov.by/eng/index.php?id=348346|title=History of the war|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Deputies from the Transcaucasus elected to the Russian Entrepreneurial Council decided to establish a Transcaucasian Sejm- the Transcaucasian Parliament as the government body in the country on February 14, 1918.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://axc.preslib.az/en_a1.html|title=Azerbaijan Democratic Republic|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
30 members of Musavat Party and the Democratic Party of Neutral people, 7 members from the Muslim Socialists, 3 members from the İttihad Party, 4 members from the Democratic Socialist-Democratic Menshevik Party, included to Transcaucasian Sejm.(Parliament) As a result, 44 Azerbaijanis took place the Transcaucasian Seim and established the Muslim fraction of the Sejm. These were:<ref name=":0" />
From "Musavat" Party and a group of Democratic neutralities: [[Mammad Yusif Jafarov]], [[Alimardan Topchubashov|AliMardan Topchubashov,]] [[Mammad Amin Rasulzadeh]], [[Nasib Yusifbeyli|Nasib Yusifbayli]], [[Hasan bey Aghayev]], [[Khosrov bey Sultanov|Khosrov bay Sultanov]], [[Mammad Hasan Hajinski|Mammadhasan Hajinski]], Mir Hidayat bay Seyidov, [[Fatali Khan Khoyski]], [[Khalil Khasmammadov|Khalil bey Khasmammadov]], Ahmed Bey Mahammadbeyov, [[Aslan bey Gardashov]], Shafi bay Rustambeyli, [[Javad Malik-Yeganov]], [[Mustafa Mahmudov]], Mehdi bey Hajibababeyov, Haji Selim Akhundzadeh, [[Mehdi bey Hajinski|Mehdi bey Hacinski]], [[Khudadat bey Malik-Aslanov]], Museyib bey Eqikanova, Lutfali bey Behbudov, [[Firidun bey Kocharli|Firudin bey Kocharli]], Ibrahim aga Vakilov, [[Hamid bey Shahtakhtinski|Hamid bey Shakhtakhtinski]], Rahim bay Vakilov, Alasgar bey Mahmudbeyov, Yusif Efendizade, Mirza Jamal Yusifzade, Mammadrza aga Vakilov, Islam bey Gabulzadeh.<ref name=":0" />
== Adoption == On 28 May 1918 in the palace of the former governor of the Russian emperor in the Caucasus in Tiflis, in the blue saloon for Muslim group of [[Transcaucasian Seim]] members of [[Azerbaijan National Council]] gathered at the meeting chaired by Dr. [[Hasan bey Aghayev]].<ref name="Элм"/> Dr. Hasan bey Aghayev informed the participants about the collapse of the Transcaucasian Sejm, as well as prevailing in the region internal and external situation.<ref name="Элм"/> Aghayev put the consideration of the free and independent Azerbaijan. After a long and thorough discussion, the Secretary [[Mustafa Mahmudov]] read the names of voters; 24 votes, with 2 abstentions, adopted a Declaration of Independence of Azerbaijan.<ref name="Элм"/> The Declaration was signed by [[Hasan bey Aghayev]], [[Fatali Khan Khoyski]], [[Nasib Yusifbeyli]], [[Jamo bey Hajinski]], Shafi bey Rustambeyli, [[Nariman bey Narimanbeyov]], [[Javad Malik-Yeganov]] and [[Mustafa Mahmudov]]. Only Jafar Ahundov and one of the leaders of the party "[[Ittihad]]" Majid Sultan Ghani Zadeh didn't vote for the adoption of the Declaration.<ref>Oğuztoğrul Tahirli. [http://www.anl.az/down/meqale/525/2011/dekabr/220148.htm Zaqafqaziya Seyminin üzvü Cəfər Axundov]. (Azerbaijani) // 525-ci qəzet. — 17 December 2011. — P. 28.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.azerbaijan.az/_StatePower/_LegislativePower/legislativePower_01_e.html|title=History of Independent State and Parlament|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Monument === Monument of the Independence Declaration erected on the Istiglaliyyat Street in honor of the [[Azerbaijan Democratic Republic]] was opened on May 25, 2007. Independence Declaration (adopted in Tbilisi, 1918) in both version written with former Azerbaijani letters and the Latin alphabet were carved on the monument. President [[Ilham Aliyev]] attended in the opening ceremony. The monument was erected between the building of the [[Institute of Manuscripts of Azerbaijan|Institute of Manuscripts of the Azerbaijan]] and the building of the [[Azerbaijan State University of Economics|Azerbaijan State University of Economic]] .<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aztv.az/readnews.php?lang=en&id=613|title=President Ilham Aliyev visited the monument to the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic in Istiglaliyyat Street on the occasion of May 28 - the Republic Day|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== State holiday === On the day of adoption of the Declaration of Independence - the Republic day of Azerbaijan is celebrated as a state holiday since May 28, 1990.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.officeholidays.com/countries/azerbaijan/index.php|title=National Public Holidays of Azerbaijan|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.president.az/azerbaijan/holidays|title=Holidays|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Annotated text of the Declaration == {{quote| 1. Azerbaijan is a fully sovereign state; it consists of the southern and eastern parts of Transcaucasia under the authority of the Azerbaijani people.
2. It is resolved that the form of government of the independent Azerbaijani state is a democratic republic.
3. The Azerbaijani Democratic Republic is determined to establish friendly relations with all, especially with the neighboring nations and states.
4. The Azerbaijani Democratic Republic guarantees to all its citizens within its borders full civil and political rights, regardless of ethnic origin, religion, class, profession, or sex.
5. The Azerbaijani Democratic Republic encourages the free development of all nationalities inhabiting its territory.
6. Until the Azerbaijani Constituent Assembly is convened, the supreme authority over Azerbaijan is vested in a universally elected National Council and the provisional government responsible to this Council.<ref name="Swietochowski">[[Tadeusz Swietochowski]]. [https://books.google.com/books?id=cozSOSsv7ZsC&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=The+Azerbaijan+Democratic+Republic+guarantees+to+all+its+citizens+within+its+borders+full+civil+and+political+rights,+regardless+of+ethnic+origin,+religion,+class,+profession,+or+sex.&source=bl&ots=DQ_uHHhLVS&sig=p012zbDx_SDF5hzdmfANwmFbqeU&hl=ru&ei=Q4CBS__oEprUmgPsr4TvBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Azerbaijan%20Democratic%20Republic%20guarantees%20to%20all%20its%20citizens%20within%20its%20borders%20full%20civil%20and%20political%20rights%2C%20regardless%20of%20ethnic%20origin%2C%20religion%2C%20class%2C%20profession%2C%20or%20sex.&f=false ''Russia and Azerbaijan: A Borderland in Transition'']. New York: Columbia University Press, 1995. {{ISBN|0231070683}}, p. 129</ref>}}
== References == {{reflist}}
{{commons category|Declaration of Independence (Azerbaijan)}} {{Azerbaijan Democratic Republic}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Declaration Of Independence (Azerbaijan)}} [[Category:1918 in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:1918 in international relations]] [[Category:Declarations of independence|Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Modern history of Azerbaijan]] [[Category:May 1918 events]] [[Category:1918 documents]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} [[File:Risperdal tablets.jpg|thumb|right|Tablets in a [[blister pack]] in folding [[carton]]]]
'''Pharmaceutical packaging''' (or '''drug packaging''') is the packages and the [[packaging]] processes for [[Pharmaceutical drug|pharmaceutical preparations]]. It involves all of the operations from production through [[drug distribution]] channels to the end consumer.
Pharmaceutical packaging is highly regulated but with some variation in the details, depending on the country of origin or the region. Several common factors can include: assurance of patient safety, assurance of the efficacy of the drug through the intended [[shelf life]], uniformity of the drug through different production lots, thorough documentation of all materials and processes, control of possible migration of packaging components into the drug, control of degradation of the drug by oxygen, moisture, heat, etc., prevention of [[microbial]] contamination, sterility, etc. Packaging is often involved in dispensing, dosing, and use of the pharmaceutical product. Communication of proper use and cautionary labels are also regulated. Packaging is an integral part of pharmaceutical product. <ref>{{Cite book | last = Santoro | first = MIRM | chapter =Pharmaceutical Packaging | editor-last = Yam | editor-first = K L | title = Encyclopedia of Packaging Technology | pages =205–216 | publisher =Wiley | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-0-470-08704-6}}</ref> <ref> {{cite journal | last = Kunal | first = Mehta | last2 = | first2 = | date = July 2012 | title = Recent Trends in Pharmaceutical Packaging: A Review | url = http://ijpcsonline.com/files/51-194.pdf | journal = INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF PHARMACEUTICAL AND CHEMICAL SCIENCES | volume = 1 | issue = 3 | pages = 1282–1292 | doi = | accessdate = 24 June 2017 }}</ref>
==Segments of usage== Pharmaceutical packaging can often be thought of by the segment in the distribution system being encountered and by the functions needed by the user of the package. Packaging requirements are different.<ref> {{cite book | last =Dean | first =D A | title = Pharmaceutical Packaging Technology | publisher =Taylor and Francis | date =2000 | pages = | isbn = 0-7484-0440-6 }}</ref> [[File:Examining Bulk Drug Containers (FDA 100) (8250838700).jpg|thumb|right|Bulk drugs in fiber drums]] Bulk pharmaceuticals can be shipped to another pharmaceutical company for further processing, to a [[contract packager]] for forming unit packs, to international customers, etc. Bulk shipments might be in fiber drums (with plastic liners), [[bulk box]]es, [[corrugated box]]es with liners, [[intermediate bulk container]]s, and other [[shipping container]]s.
Smaller bulk packs can be shipped to pharmacies, particularly compounding pharmacies. The liquids or powders can be measured and put into primary packages.
Shipments to medical professionals could be at hospitals, nursing homes, veterinarians, dentists, etc. These packaged pharmaceuticals are intended to be dispensed and administered by professionally trained and certified personnel. [[File:Drugstore Ancillary Personal at work 19.JPG|thumb|right|Preparing consumer packaging of prescription drugs at pharmacy]] Drugs under prescription control are sent to pharmacies in [[multi-pack]]s of unit packs or in bottles containing many hundreds of capsules. Typically a pharmacist prepares the final form of the unit pack or places a lower count of capsules in a small bottle for the customer. In a pharmacy, pharmacists are available to answer questions and to ensure that proper documentation is provided. Internet pharmacies mail the prescribed drugs to the customer; boxes or mailing envelopes are used. Child resistant packaging is often required on the unit packs; if requested, a pharmacist is allowed put drugs in a bottle with easy open features.
Over-the-counter drugs are sold in drug stores, grocery stores, and diverse retail outlets. Usually the package needs to have all the usage information available. Packages often need to have [[tamper resistant]] features and [[child-resistant packaging]].
Usually the packaging and labeling of [[dietary supplement]]s, [[homeopathic]] drugs, and [[folk medicine]]s are not regulated. Some producers voluntarily follow the regulations for over-the-counter drugs or regional [[Pharmacopoeia]]s.
==Package forms==
The wide variety of pharmaceutical solids, liquids, and gasses are packaged in a wide variety of packages. Some of the common primary packages are:
===Blister packs=== {{Main|Blister pack}} [[File:Plaquettes de pilule.jpg|thumb|right|Birth control pills in blister packs]] Formed solid [[unit dose]]s of pharmaceuticals ([[Capsule (pharmacy) |capsules]], [[suppositories]], [[Tablet (pharmacy) | tablet]]s, etc.) are commonly packed in blister packs. In Europe about 85% of solid unit doses are packed in blister packs with only about 20% in North America.<ref>{{Citation | last =Pilchik | first =R | title =Pharmaceutical Blister Packaging, Part 1, Rationale and Materials | journal =Pharmaceutical Technology | volume = | issue = | pages =68-77 | date =November 2000 | year = | url =http://www.pharmanet.com.br/pdf/blister.pdf | accessdate = 26 June 2017}}</ref>
Blister packs are pre-formed plastic/paper/foil packaging used for formed solid drugs. The primary component of a blister pack is a cavity or pocket made from a thermoformed plastic. This usually has a backing of [[paperboard]] or a lidding seal of [[aluminum foil]] or [[plastic film]]. Blister packs are useful for protecting drugs against external factors, such as humidity and contamination for extended periods of time.
Blister packing machinery is readily available and is suited to validation processes.<ref>{{Citation | last =Pilchik | first =R | title =Pharmaceutical Blister Packaging, Part 2, Machinery and Assembly | journal =Pharmaceutical Technology | volume = | issue = | pages =56-60 | date =Dec 2000 | year = | url =http://www.pharmanet.com.br/pdf/blister.pdf | accessdate = 26 June 2017}}</ref>
===Bottles=== [[Image:Induction sealed bottle.jpg|thumb|A foil innerseal on a bottle]] {{Main|Glass bottle}} {{Main|Plastic bottle}}
Bottles are commonly used for liquid pharmaceuticals as well as formed tablets and capsules. Glass is most common for liquids because it is inert and has excellent barrier properties. Various types of plastic bottles are used both by drug producers as well as by pharmacists in a pharmacy.
Prescription bottles have been around since the 19th century.<ref name="SHA 2016">{{cite web|last1=Lindsey|first1=Bill|title=Medicinal/Chemical/Druggist Bottles|url=https://sha.org/bottle/medicinal.htm|website=sha.org|publisher=[[Society for Historical Archaeology]]|date=20 November 2016}}</ref> Throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, prescription medication bottles were called ''medicinal bottles''.<ref name="SHA 2016"/> There are many styles and shapes of prescription bottles.<ref name="SHA 2016"/>
Prescription bottles come in several different colors, the most common of which being orange or light brown due to its ability to prevent [[ultraviolet light]] from degrading the potentially photosensitive contents through [[Mechanistic organic photochemistry|photochemical reactions]], while still letting enough visible light through for the contents to be easily visible. Other common colors include: Clear (for compounds that don't degrade in light), blue, dark brown, green, and various opaque hues.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.qorpak.com/WhyShouldIChooseBrownBottles.aspx | title=Why are Many Bottles Brown? | accessdate=1 January 2014 }}</ref>
===Timed Dosing===
Some mail order pharmacies are now offering timed dosing packets for medications. They put a certain number of pills, as directed by your physician into a plastic package and print the date and time that the drugs are to be taken. It is used for people with multiple medications that are taken at different times of the day. <ref name="Pharmacy Startup PillPack Could Change The Way America Takes Its Medicine">{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/sarahhedgecock/2015/04/15/this-pharmacy-startup-wants-to-change-the-way-you-take-your-medicine/#96d9adb7de04 |title= Pharmacy Startup PillPack Could Change The Way America Takes Its Medicine |accessdate= 20 October 2017 }}</ref>
==Temperature== [[File:Cold control packaging.jpg|thumb|right|Shipment of vaccine: PU insulated box, gel packs, temp monitor, etc.]] Many pharmaceutical products are sensitive to heat or cold. Controlled distribution systems and sometimes [[cold chain]]s are required.
A mail order or [[online pharmacy]] usually ships orders by mail services or by small parcel carrier. The shipment is not temperature-controlled and it may sit in a [[Letter box|mail box]] upon delivery. Conditions can include high or low temperatures outside of the recommended storage conditions for certain products. For example, the [[USFDA]] found that the temperature in a steel mailbox painted black could reach 136 °F (58 °C) in full sun while the ambient air temperature was 101 °F (38 °C).<ref>{{cite web | last = Black | first =J. C. |author2=Layoff, T | title = Summer of 1995 – Mailbox Temperature Excurions of St Louis | work = US FDA Division of Drug Analysis | publisher = | url=http://www.layloff.net/articles/1995%20Mailbox%20Temp%20in%20STL.pdf | doi = | accessdate = 1 July 2017}}</ref> Insulated mailing envelopes are sometimes used.
Larger shipments are sent in [[insulated shipping container]]s with [[dry ice]] or [[gel pack]]s. A digital [[Temperature data logger]] or a [[time temperature indicator]] is often enclosed to monitor the temperature inside the container for its entire shipment.
==Counterfeiting== {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 200 | footer = | image1 = CD-3- Fighting Counterfeit Drugs (8675484534).jpg | caption1 = Two drug packages appear to be identical in normal light | image2 = CD-3- Fighting Counterfeit Drugs (8674379559).jpg | caption2 = Selective UV wavelength identifies counterfeit package on left}} {{Main|Counterfeit medications}} Counterfeit drugs are a serious problem; people can be taking useless drugs or even very dangerous drugs without knowing it. Custom package seals, [[authentication]] labels, [[hologram]]s, and [[security printing]], can be valued parts of an entire security system.<ref>{{Citation | last =Dallas | first =Martin | title = Anticounterfeiting Packaging 101 | journal = PharmTech | issue = | pages = | date =1 October 2014 | year = | url =http://www.pharmtech.com/anticounterfeiting-packaging-101 | accessdate = 21 January 2018}}</ref> They help verify that enclosed drugs are what the package says they are. Drug counterfeiters, however, often work with package counterfeiters, some of whom can be sophisticated. No packaging system is completely secure.
==Prescription labels== Medication packaging includes a document that provides information about that drug and its use. For [[prescription medication]]s, the insert is [[Technical writing|technical]], and provides information for [[Health professional|medical professionals]] about how to prescribe the drug. Package inserts for prescription drugs often include a separate document called a "patient package insert" with information written in [[Plain English|plain language]] intended for the [[end-user]] -- the person who will take the drug or give the drug to another person, for example a minor. Inserts for [[over-the-counter medication]]]s are also written plainly.<ref name=Nathan>{{cite journal |last1=Nathan |first1=Joseph P. |last2=Vider |first2=Etty |title=The Package Insert |journal=US Pharm. |date=2015 |volume=40 |issue=5 |pages=8-10. |url=https://www.uspharmacist.com/article/the-package-insert |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Nadine Vanlaer |title=Drug Package Inserts: the Letter of the Law - Packaging Gateway |url=https://www.packaging-gateway.com/features/feature755/ |work=Packaging Gateway |date=August 31, 2006}}</ref><ref name="Reading labels">{{cite web|author1=Consumer Reports|authorlink1=Consumer Reports|title=Drug Safety: Reading Labels and Patient Information|url=http://consumerhealthchoices.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/ReadingLabels1.pdf|website=consumerreports.org|date=January 2012}}</ref><ref name="Take as directed">{{cite web|author1=Consumer Reports|authorlink1=Consumer Reports|title=Drug Safety: Taking Drugs as Directed|url=http://consumerhealthchoices.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/TakingAsDirected.pdf|website=consumerreports.org|date=January 2012}}</ref>
In the US the document is called "prescribing information" or the "package insert" (PI) and layperson's document is called the "patient package insert" (PPI).<ref name=Nathan/> In Europe the technical document is called the "summary of product characteristics" and the document for end-users is called the "package leaflet".<ref name=EMA>{{cite web |title=Marketing authorisation - Product-information requirements |url=http://www.ema.europa.eu/ema/index.jsp?curl=pages/regulation/general/general_content_000199.jsp&mid=WC0b01ac0580022bb3 |publisher=European Medicines Agency |accessdate=18 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
The bottle or box also has information printed on it, intended for the person taking the medication.<ref name="Take as directed"/>
==Packaging production== {{Main|Validation (drug manufacture)}} [[File:Laboratoires Arkopharma - Chaine de conditionnement remplissage piluliers.JPG|thumb|right|Example pharmaceutical packaging line]] All aspects of pharmaceutical production, including packaging, are tightly controlled and have regulatory requirements. Uniformity, cleanliness, sterility, and other requirements are needed to maintain [[Good Manufacturing Practice]]s.
Product safety management is vital. A complete [[Quality Management System]] must be in place. Validation involves collecting documentary evidence of all aspects of compliance.<ref> {{cite journal | date = 13 March 2010 | title = Validation in Pharmaceutical Industry, Types of Validation | url =http://www.pharmacistspharmajournal.org/2010/03/validation-in-pharmaceutical.html#.WVJM2saZNsM| journal = International Journal of Research in Pharmaceutical and Biomedical Sciences | volume = | issue = | pages = | doi = | accessdate = 26 June 2017 }}</ref><ref> {{Citation | last =Jatto | first =E | author-link = | last2 =Okhamafe | first2 =A O | author2-link = | title = An Overview of Pharmaceutical Validation and Process Controls in Drug Development | journal =Tropical Journal of Pharmaceutical Research | volume =1 | issue =2 | pages =115-122 | date =Dec 2002 | orig-year = | year = | url =https://www.ajol.info/index.php/tjpr/article/viewFile/14592/16163 | accessdate = 26 June 2017 }}</ref> [[Hazard analysis and critical control points]] is a methodology which has been proven useful. <ref> {{Citation | last =Dahija | first =S | last2 =Kar, Chhikara | first2 = | title = Opportunities, challenges and benefits of using HACCP as a quality risk management tool in the pharmaceutical industry | journal =The Quality Assurance Journal | volume =12 | issue =2 | pages =95-104 | date =April 2009 | orig-year = | year = | url =http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/qaj.446/epdf | accessdate = 29 June 2017 }}</ref> Quality assurance extends beyond the packaging operations through distribution and cold chain management; Good [[drug distribution|distribution]] practice is often a regulatory requirement.
With a large portion of pharmaceutical packaging being outsourced to [[contract packager]]s, additional demand is being placed on specialty areas, i.e. specialty dosage forms.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pharmpro.com/news/2016/11/cmo-report-two-thirds-pharma-manufacturing-outsourced|title=Two-thirds of pharmaceutical manufacturing is outsourced; preferred providers pick up largest share|last=|first=|date=|website=Pharmaceutical Processing|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
==Examples== <gallery> File:Childproof.jpg|Example of two types of child-resistant safety caps File:Animal medication veterinary pharmaceutical bottles.JPG|Veterinary supplies File:Pill box with pills.JPG|Pill box for home File:Components of a Adalimumab-Humira pen - annotated.jpg|Components of injectable package BECONASE nasal spray.JPG|Nasal spray<ref>{{Citation| last =Cheng| first = Y S| title = Characterization of Nasal Spray Pumps and Deposition Pattern in a Replica of the Human Nasal Airway| journal = Journal of Aerosol Medicine | volume =14| issue =2| pages =267-280| date =| year =2001| month =| url =https://www.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/08942680152484199| access-date = 2 June 2018}}</ref> Gardasil vaccine and box new.jpg|Vaccine Image:Infuuszakjes.jpg|Intravenous therapy File:Fucidin 2pct 15g.jpg|Tube of ointment File:Ampoule pharmaceutique.JPG|[[Ampoule]]s Drop counter and vial.JPG|Drop counter Tpn 3bag.jpg|[[Parenteral nutrition]] kit File:Enema prepared, disposable.jpg|A prepared, disposable [[enema]] File:DoD random drug test specimen bottle.png|Drug test bottle with authentication seal Image:Inhaler2.jpg|A [[metered-dose inhaler]] (MDI) File:Epi-Pen 2016.jpg |Epinephrine autoinjector File:Medicijnflesje met doorprikstop.JPG|tearable metal band on pharmaceutical bottle File:Faltschachteln mit integriertem RFID-Tag.jpg|rfid chip built into drug package File:Walgreens Prescription Bottle.jpg|Prescription Bottle </gallery>

Retrieved 8 April 2018. | international = ''None'' | colours = [[Red]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-10-14-red-tide-from-economic-freedom-to-white-genocide-extremism-grabs-the-spotlight/#.UnQCyhb1DoF|title=Red Tide: From 'economic freedom' to 'white genocide', extremism grabs the spotlight (in English)|publisher=[[Daily Maverick]]|date=14 October 2013|accessdate=1 November 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017020415/http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-10-14-red-tide-from-economic-freedom-to-white-genocide-extremism-grabs-the-spotlight/#.UnQCyhb1DoF|archivedate=17 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} | slogan = "People’s Power for Economic Freedom in Our Lifetime" | seats1_title = [[National Assembly of South Africa|National Assembly]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|25|400|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[National Council of Provinces]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|7|90|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} | seats3_title = [[Pan-African Parliament]] | seats3 = {{Composition bar|1|5|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} | seats4_title = [[Provincial legislature (South Africa)|Provincial Legislatures]] | seats4 = {{Composition bar|30|430|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} | seats5_title = [[City of Johannesburg Metropolitan Municipality]] (council) | seats5 = {{Composition bar|30|270|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} | seats6_title = [[Nelson Mandela Bay Metropolitan Municipality]] (council) | seats6 = {{Composition bar|6|120|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} | seats7_title = [[City of Cape Town]] (council) | seats7 = {{Composition bar|7|231|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} | flag = | website = {{Official URL}} | country = South Africa }} The '''Economic Freedom Fighters''' ('''EFF''') is a [[South Africa]]n [[Far-left politics|far-left]] [[political party]]. It was started by expelled former [[African National Congress Youth League]] (ANCYL) President [[Julius Malema]], and his allies, in 2013.{{cite news|title=Malema launches his Economic Freedom Fighters|author=Meggan Saville|url=http://www.dispatch.co.za/malema-launches-his-economic-freedom-fighters/|newspaper=Dispatch Online|date=12 July 2013|accessdate=16 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725200305/http://www.dispatch.co.za/malema-launches-his-economic-freedom-fighters/|archivedate=25 July 2013|df=dmy-all}} Malema is President of the EFF, heading the Central Command Team which serves as the central structure of the party.{{cite news|title=Malema takes command of Economic Freedom Fighters|author=Setumo Stone|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2013/07/11/malema-takes-command-of-economic-freedom-fighters|newspaper=[[Business Day (South Africa)|Business Day]]|date=11 July 2013|accessdate=16 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130714113641/http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2013/07/11/malema-takes-command-of-economic-freedom-fighters|archivedate=14 July 2013|df=dmy-all}} It is currently the third-largest party in both houses of the [[Parliament of South Africa|South African Parliament]], receiving 1,169,259 votes and a 6.35% share of the vote in the [[South African general election, 2014|2014 general election]]. {{Citation needed span|text=By December 2014, the EFF claimed to have over half a million members, although this has not been independently verified.|date=August 2018|reason=not verified independtly, not even a source that we can use to cite EFF saying that they even have those numbers}} ==History== At a 26 July 2013 press briefing in [[Soweto]], Malema announced that the new party had over 1000 members, double the 500 required for registration with the [[Electoral Commission of South Africa|Independent Electoral Commission]] (IEC).{{cite news|title=EFF readies for election registration as over 1 000 members recruited|author=SAPA|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2013/07/28/eff-readies-for-election-registration-as-over-1-000-members-recruited|newspaper=[[The Times (South Africa)|The Times]]|date=28 July 2013|accessdate=28 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730092849/http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2013/07/28/eff-readies-for-election-registration-as-over-1-000-members-recruited|archivedate=30 July 2013|df=dmy-all}} The EFF is now registered with the IEC, after an objection to its registration by the [[Freedom Front Plus]] (FF+) was dismissed in September 2013.{{cite news|title=It's official: Malema's EFF is a political party|author=Verashni Pillay|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2013-09-05-malemas-eff-to-contest-2014-elections|newspaper=[[Mail & Guardian]]|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=5 September 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907063401/http://mg.co.za/article/2013-09-05-malemas-eff-to-contest-2014-elections|archivedate=7 September 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==Splinters and infighting== In 2015, the EFF suspended [[Member of parliament|MP]] Lucky Twala and expelled three MPs, Mpho Ramakatsa, Andile Mngxitama and [[Khanyisile Litchfield-Tshabalala]].{{cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Litchfield-Tshabalala-UDMs-new-national-organiser-20150605|title=Litchfield-Tshabalala UDM's new national organiser|author=Genevieve Quintal|date=2015-06-05|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930022925/http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Litchfield-Tshabalala-UDMs-new-national-organiser-20150605|archivedate=30 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} Mngxitama formed his own party, named [[Black First Land First]] (BLF), while Litchfield-Tshabalala joined the [[United Democratic Movement]]. ==Policies== [[File:EFF land march on Mandela Day 2014.JPG|thumb|A small march by the EFF on Mandela Day (18 July) 2014 near the parliament building in [[Cape Town]] protesting in support of [[land reform in South Africa]].]] The EFF "draws inspiration from the broad [[Marxism–Leninism|Marxist–Leninist]] tradition and [[Frantz Fanon|Fanonian]] schools of thought in their analyses of the state, imperialism, culture and class contradictions in every society", according to one of its declarations.{{cite web|url=https://www.effonline.org/declaration|title=Declaration|work=effonline.org}} It criticises the [[African National Congress]] and their primary opposition, the [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]], for their allegedly pro-business stances, which it claims have sold out the black people of South Africa to capitalism as cheap labour. It promises to tackle corruption, provide quality social housing, and provide free primary healthcare and education for all, as well as proposing to [[expropriation|expropriate]] stolen land, nationalise the mining and banking sectors, double welfare grants and the minimum wage, and end the proposed toll system for highways. The EFF takes significant inspiration from [[Thomas Sankara]] in terms of both style and ideology.{{cite news|last=Duval Smith|first=Alex|date=30 April 2014|title='Africa's Che Guevara': Thomas Sankara's legacy|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27219307|newspaper=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]]|location=[[London]]|accessdate=5 November 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141101053949/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27219307|archivedate=1 November 2014|df=dmy-all}} In a May 2014 column, the prominent EFF member Jackie Shandu declared his party a "proudly Sankarist formation".{{cite news|last=Shandu|first=Jackie|date=22 May 2014|title=The Sankarist makings of the EFF|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2014-05-22-the-sankarist-makings-of-eff/#.VFqe0d186rX|newspaper=[[Daily Maverick]]|location=[[Johannesburg]]|accessdate=5 November 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141106000454/http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2014-05-22-the-sankarist-makings-of-eff/#.VFqe0d186rX|archivedate=6 November 2014|df=dmy-all}} The EFF has been vocal in its criticism of black business owners and black owners of mining companies in South Africa. In an address at the Oxford Union in November 2015, Malema spoke out against billionaire mining company owner Patrice Motsepe.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2015/11/26/effs-malema-takes-aim-at-sellout-black-billionaires-in-oxford-address|title=Business Day|website=www.bdlive.co.za|access-date=2016-11-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151229135821/http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2015/11/26/effs-malema-takes-aim-at-sellout-black-billionaires-in-oxford-address|archivedate=29 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2016/05/01/Patrice-Motsepe-has-no-power%E2%80%9A-says-Malema|title=Patrice Motsepe has no power‚ says Malema|last=Jordaan|first=Buchule Raba And Nomahlubi|website=Times LIVE|access-date=2016-11-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127215142/http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2016/05/01/Patrice-Motsepe-has-no-power%E2%80%9A-says-Malema|archivedate=27 November 2016|df=dmy-all}} Further protests in 2015, the EFF delivered demands that included the socialization of the mining sector and called for more explicit targets for the 26% BEE ownership required by law.{{Cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2015-11-01-yes-and-no-to-effs-list-of-demands|title=Yes and no to EFF’s list of demands|last=John|first=Victoria|newspaper=The M&G Online|access-date=2016-11-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128050240/http://mg.co.za/article/2015-11-01-yes-and-no-to-effs-list-of-demands|archivedate=28 November 2016|df=dmy-all}} Malema addressed a crowd in Marikana, Rustenburg in the platinum mining area, blaming mining companies and calling out platinum mining company Lonmin in particular, for poverty in the region.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/bdd0ce804d689dfe9d42df4b5facb1b5/Malema-blames-mining-companies-for-high-levels-of-poverty-20160707|title=SABC News - Malema blames mining companies for high levels of poverty:Thursday 7 July 2016|last=Tatai|first=Sello|website=www.sabc.co.za|access-date=2016-11-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127232029/http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/bdd0ce804d689dfe9d42df4b5facb1b5/Malema-blames-mining-companies-for-high-levels-of-poverty-20160707|archivedate=27 November 2016|df=dmy-all}} The party supports the re-introduction of the [[Capital punishment in South Africa|death penalty]].{{cite web |url=http://news.iafrica.com/sa/883240.html |title=iafrica.com Juju wants death penalty |website=News.iafrica.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-19 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160901181605/http://news.iafrica.com/sa/883240.html |archivedate=1 September 2016 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.economicfreedomfighters.org/malema-wants-death-penalty-efflaunch/ |title=Malema wants death penalty #EFFlaunch | Economic Freedom Fighters - EFF |publisher=Economic Freedom Fighters |date=2013-10-13 |accessdate=2016-01-19 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126014743/http://www.economicfreedomfighters.org/malema-wants-death-penalty-efflaunch/ |archivedate=26 January 2016 |df=dmy-all }} In 2016, after [[2016 South African Local Government elections|local elections]] in South Africa, the EFF has suggested that they will back the Democratic Alliance in hung-metro areas, but would not be entering into a coalition with any political party in South Africa.{{Cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-08-17-malema-says-the-eff-wont-form-coalitions-but-will-support-da-in-hung-metros|title=Malema says the EFF won't form coalitions, but will support DA in hung metros|last=Feltham|first=Luke|newspaper=The M&G Online|access-date=2016-11-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161128050103/http://mg.co.za/article/2016-08-17-malema-says-the-eff-wont-form-coalitions-but-will-support-da-in-hung-metros|archivedate=28 November 2016|df=dmy-all}} The EFF was the only parliamentary party that opposed the 2018 political party funding bill.https://citizen.co.za/news/south-africa/1871025/reasons-why-the-eff-rejects-the-political-party-funding-bill/ ==High-profile members== High-profile members of the Central Command Team include [[Floyd Shivambu]], [[Fana Mokoena]] and [[Mbuyiseni Ndlozi]] (National Spokesperson).{{cite web|author=Economic Freedom Fighters|date=|title=Central Command Team|url=http://www.effonline.org/structure|publisher=effonline.org|accessdate=21 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812200344/http://effighters.org.za/structure/officials/|archivedate=12 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} Controversial businessman [[Kenny Kunene]] joined the Central Command Team in July 2013 before resigning from the Central Command Team on 20 August 2013 and from the organisation on 26 August 2013.{{cite news|title='Sushi King' quits EFF leadership|author=Poloko Tau|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/special-features/sushi-king-quits-eff-leadership-1.1565564#.UhhxMWthiSM|newspaper=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|Independent Online]]|date=21 August 2013|accessdate=24 August 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130824143456/http://www.iol.co.za/news/special-features/sushi-king-quits-eff-leadership-1.1565564#.UhhxMWthiSM|archivedate=24 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=Kunene quits EFF|author=[[South African Press Association|SAPA]]|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Kunene-quits-EFF-20130826|newspaper=[[News24]]|date=26 August 2013|accessdate=5 September 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130829084845/http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Kunene-quits-EFF-20130826|archivedate=29 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} On 4 November 2013, it was announced that Dali Mpofu had left the [[African National Congress]] (ANC) after 33 years of membership and joined the EFF.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.iol.co.za/capetimes/dali-mpofu-joins-eff-1.1601553#.UoctTNKmimg|title=Dali Mpofu joins EFF - Cape Times|publisher=IOL.co.za|date=2013-11-04|accessdate=2013-11-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202233822/http://www.iol.co.za/capetimes/dali-mpofu-joins-eff-1.1601553#.UoctTNKmimg|archivedate=2 December 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==Support base== According to a November 2013 [[Ipsos]] survey, the party's supporters are younger than average, with 49% being younger than 24, overwhelmingly black (99%) and mostly male, with women representing only 33% of the support base. A disproportionate number of supporters live in Malema's home province of [[Limpopo]] (28%), while only 1% live in [[KwaZulu-Natal]], a more populous province.{{cite web|title=The supporter profiles of SA`s three largest parties|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page72308?oid=534039&sn=Marketingweb+detail&pid=90389|publisher=Politicsweb|accessdate=6 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222022154/http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page72308?oid=534039&sn=Marketingweb+detail&pid=90389|archivedate=22 February 2014|df=dmy-all}} The party was expected to make an impact in the [[South African general election, 2014|2014 general election]], taking between 4 per cent and 8 per cent of the national vote. This was potentially enough for the party to hold [[Balance of power (parliament)|the balance of power]] in provinces where the governing African National Congress was in danger of losing its absolute majority.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/africa/economic-freedom-fighters-on-rise-in-south-africa-1.1779028|title=Economic Freedom Fighters on rise in South Africa|date=1 May 2014|accessdate=6 May 2014|publisher=''The Irish Times''|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506162746/http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/africa/economic-freedom-fighters-on-rise-in-south-africa-1.1779028|archivedate=6 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} In fact, the ANC retained its absolute majority, but the EFF moved into third place, surging past the shrinking [[Inkatha Freedom Party]], with a 6.35% share of the vote to the IFP's 2.40%. ==Election results== ===National elections=== ====National Assembly==== {{election table|editlink=no}} |- !Election !Total votes !Share of vote !Seats !+/– !Government |- ![[South African general election, 2014|2014]]{{Cite web|title=2014 National and Provincial Elections Results - 2014 National and Provincial Election Results|url=http://www.elections.org.za/resultsNPE2014/|publisher=IEC|accessdate=11 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510231542/http://www.elections.org.za/resultsNPE2014/|archivedate=10 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} |1,169,259 |6.35 |{{Composition bar|25|400|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} |{{increase}} 25 |{{no2|in opposition}} |} ====National Council of Provinces==== {{election table|editlink=no}} |- !Election !Total # of
seats won !+/– |- ![[South African general election, 2014|2014]] |{{Composition bar|7|90|hex={{Economic Freedom Fighters/meta/color}}}} |{{increase}} 7 |} ===Municipal elections=== {{election table|editlink=no}} |- !Election !Votes !% |- ![[South African municipal election, 2016|2016]]{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.org.za/content/LGEPublicReports/402/Detailed%20Results/National.pdf|title=Results Summary - All Ballots|publisher=elections.org.za|accessdate=11 August 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808191111/http://www.elections.org.za/content/LGEPublicReports/402/Detailed%20Results/National.pdf|archivedate=8 August 2016|df=dmy-all}} |3,202,679 |8.31% |- |} ===Provincial elections=== {{election table|editlink=no}} !rowspan=2|Election !colspan=2|[[Eastern Cape]] !colspan=2|[[Free State (province)|Free State]] !colspan=2|[[Gauteng]] !colspan=2|[[KwaZulu-Natal|Kwazulu-Natal]] !colspan=2|[[Limpopo]] !colspan=2|[[Mpumalanga]] !colspan=2|[[North West (South African province)|North-West]] !colspan=2|[[Northern Cape]] !colspan=2|[[Western Cape]] |- !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats |- ![[South African general election, 2014|2014]] |3.48%||2/63 |8.15%||2/30 |10.30%||8/73 |1.85%||2/80 |10.74%||6/49 |6.26%||2/30 |13.21%||5/33 |4.96%||2/30 |2.11%||1/42 |} ==Achievements== On 6 August 2015 the EFF announced that it has secured a Constitutional court case for its [[Jacob Zuma]] campaign of "#PayBackTheMoney". The case was heard on the 9 February 2016. The Judgement was released by Chief Justice Mogoeng Mogoeng. The judgement stated that The President has violated the Constitution of South Africa, along with the [[Speaker of the National Assembly of South Africa|Speaker of the National Assembly]] [[Baleka Mbete]]. The President was given 60 days to fulfill the requirements of the Public Protector [[Thuli Madonsela]].{{cite news|title=Lets meet in court, Malema tells Zuma|author=Emsie Ferreira|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/special-features/lets-meet-in-court-malema-tells-zuma-1896636|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=26 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201155340/http://www.iol.co.za/news/special-features/lets-meet-in-court-malema-tells-zuma-1896636|archivedate=1 February 2016|df=dmy-all}} On 27 February 2018 the EFF tabled a motion in The National Assembly to amend the Constitution so as to allow for the expropriation of land without compensation. The motion, brought by the EFF leader [[Julius Malema]], was adopted with a vote of 241 in support, and 83 against. The only parties who did not support the motion were the [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]], [[Freedom Front Plus]], [[Cope]] and the [[African Christian Democratic Party|ACDP]]. Land Expropriation is one of the EFF's Seven cardinal pillars.{{cite news|title=National Assembly adopts motion on land expropriation without compensation|author=Jan Gerber|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/breaking-national-assembly-adopts-motion-on-land-expropriation-without-compensation-20180227 |date=27 February 2018 |accessdate=12 October 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920012156/https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/breaking-national-assembly-adopts-motion-on-land-expropriation-without-compensation-20180227|archivedate=2018-09-20|df=dmy-all}} In 2018, the student wing of the EFF, the EFF Student Command won many universities across the country. The red berets defeated the ANC-aligned [[South African Students Congress]] (Sasco) at the [[Durban University of Technology]], the [[University of Zululand]] and [[Mangosuthu University of Technology]]. They also won in Cape Town, the District Six, Mowbray and Bellville [[Cape Peninsula University of Technology]] (CPUT) campuses with landslide victories, meaning they now are in charge of the institution's SRC. They also won the [[University of Cape Town]]. Peter Keetse, president of the EFFSC, said the win was a warning shot for what was going to happen in 2019 national general elections. He said the youth were the influencers of the future, “therefore, this is an indication of what is to follow”.{{cite news|title=Comrades see red as students back EFF on campus|author=Kwandokuhle Njoli|url=https://www.iol.co.za/sunday-tribune/news/comrades-see-red-as-students-back-eff-on-campus-17275465|date=30 September 2018|accessdate=12 October 2018|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} ==Criticisms and controversies== The ANC has accused the Zimbabwean ruling party, the [[ZANU–PF|Zimbabwe African National Union – Patriotic Front]] (ZANU–PF), of supporting the EFF in order to destabilise the ANC.{{cite news|title=Mantashe hits out at EFF for 'distorting the Freedom Charter'|author=Natasha Marrian|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2013/07/29/mantashe-hits-out-at-eff-for-distorting-the-freedom-charter|newspaper=Business Day|date=29 July 2013|accessdate=30 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801072713/http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2013/07/29/mantashe-hits-out-at-eff-for-distorting-the-freedom-charter|archivedate=1 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} ===Ideology=== Feminists and the [[National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa]] have criticised the party's militarism and "military command structure".{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/special-features/numsa-wary-of-capitalist-malema-1.1627179#.Usa_NvQW3Y5 |title=Numsa wary of ‘capitalist’ Malema |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103182553/http://www.iol.co.za/news/special-features/numsa-wary-of-capitalist-malema-1.1627179 |archive-date=3 January 2014 |author=Shanti Aboobaker |work=Sunday Independent |date=29 December 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/siphokazimagadla/2013/11/06/eff-and-the-return-of-the-warrior-citizen/ |title=EFF & the Return of the Warrior Citizen |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140410024005/http://www.thoughtleader.co.za/siphokazimagadla/2013/11/06/eff-and-the-return-of-the-warrior-citizen |archive-date=10 April 2014 |author=Siphokazi Magadla |work=Thought Leader |date=2013}} In mid-June 2016 a group calling themselves "Anonymous Africa", claiming to be associated with the [[Hacktivism|hacktivist]] group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]], perpetrated a [[Denial-of-service attack|DDoS attack]] on the EFF's website stating the reason for the attack was the party's "nationalist socialist rhetoric".{{Cite web|url=http://www.fin24.com/Tech/Companies/exclusive-why-anonymous-hacked-the-sabc-guptas-20160617|title=EXCLUSIVE: Why Anonymous 'hacked' the SABC, Gupta websites|website=Fin24|access-date=2016-06-19|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617140057/http://www.fin24.com/Tech/Companies/exclusive-why-anonymous-hacked-the-sabc-guptas-20160617|archivedate=17 June 2016|df=dmy-all}} The [[South African Communist Party]] also condemns this party.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sacp.org.za/main.php?ID=5299|title=SACP supports ANC, condemns Julius Malema`s propagation of war in the strongest possible terms, calls on the police ?to act swiftly in terms of the rule of law|website=www.sacp.org.za|access-date=2018-06-18}} ===Violence and bigotry=== Vusi Khoza, the party's candidate for [[Premier of KwaZulu-Natal]], has a criminal conviction for his involvement in what was believed to be a xenophobic attack on foreigners at Albert Park, [[Durban]] in December 2009.[http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/eff-s-kzn-man-has-criminal-past-1.1663164#.Uy0Y3vmSzY4 EFF’s KZN man has criminal past] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322091149/http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/eff-s-kzn-man-has-criminal-past-1.1663164 |date=22 March 2014 }}, BHEKI MBANJWA, ''The Daily News'', 2014 Feminists have characterised leading members of the party as misogynist.[http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-04-25-floyd-shivambu-despicable-me/ Floyd Shivambu: Despicable Me] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224084746/http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-04-25-floyd-shivambu-despicable-me |date=24 December 2013 }}, Sipho Hlongwane, ''The Daily Maverick'', 2012[http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-11-05-remembering-thomas-sankara-the-effs-muse/ Remembering Thomas Sankara, the EFF’s muse] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224094726/http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-11-05-remembering-thomas-sankara-the-effs-muse/ |date=24 December 2013 }}, Rebecca Davis, ''The Daily Maverick'', 2013[http://feministssa.com/2013/11/28/elections-analysis-the-economic-freedom-fighters-2/ Elections Analysis: The Economic Freedom Fighters] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322090232/http://feministssa.com/2013/11/28/elections-analysis-the-economic-freedom-fighters-2/ |date=22 March 2014 }}, Sonja Bornman, ''Feminist SA'', 2013[http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-11-25-eff-two-senior-party-officials-accused-of-involvement-in-2008-gang-rape EFF: Two senior party officials accused of involvement in 2008 gang rape] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322091542/http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-11-25-eff-two-senior-party-officials-accused-of-involvement-in-2008-gang-rape |date=22 March 2014 }}, Rebecca Davis, ''The Daily Maverick'', 2013 The EFF is widely criticised for inciting and perpetuating racism.[http://sacsis.org.za/site/article/1899 The EFF and the Question of National Unity] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413154904/http://sacsis.org.za/site/article/1899 |date=13 April 2014 }}, Duncan, Jane, ''SACSIS WEBSITE'', 29 JAN, 2014{{Cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/eff-must-paybackthemoney-for-damage-to-varsities-1995188|title=‘EFF must #PayBackTheMoney for damage to varsities’|last=Sain|first=Raahil|date=2016-03-08|work=|access-date=2017-04-14|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414162203/http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/eff-must-paybackthemoney-for-damage-to-varsities-1995188|archivedate=14 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} South Africa's [[Electoral Commission of South Africa|Independent Electoral Commission]] disqualified an EFF councillor in the 2016 local elections due to racism.{{Cite news|url=http://www.enca.com/south-africa/iec-disqualifies-eff-councillor-for-racist-tweet|title=IEC disqualifies EFF councillor for racist tweet|last=|first=|date=2016-08-29|work=eNCA|access-date=2017-04-14|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414082702/http://www.enca.com/south-africa/iec-disqualifies-eff-councillor-for-racist-tweet|archivedate=14 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} In February, 2016, during violent university protests characterised by arson and vandalism, EFF Youth leader Omphile Seleke posted instructions for making petrol bombs on social media.{{Cite news|url=http://citizen.co.za/news/news-national/1013882/effs-petrol-bomb-recipe-fuels-tuks-fears/|title=EFF’s ‘petrol bomb recipe’ fuels Tuks fears|last=de Lange|first=Ilse|date=2016-02-29|work=The Citizen|access-date=2017-04-14|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414081535/http://citizen.co.za/news/news-national/1013882/effs-petrol-bomb-recipe-fuels-tuks-fears/|archivedate=14 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} Malema stated at a political rally in 2016 that “We [the EFF] are not calling for the slaughter of [[white people]]‚ at least for now". When asked for comment by a news agency, the ANC spokesperson, Zizi Kodwa stated that there will be no comment from the ANC, as "[h]e [Malema] was addressing his own party supporters."{{cite news|title=Malema slammed for comments on whites|url=http://www.enca.com/south-africa/malema-%E2%80%98slaughter-statement%E2%80%99-rocks-sa|accessdate=30 May 2017|publisher=ENCA|date=8 November 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170417053045/http://www.enca.com/south-africa/malema-%E2%80%98slaughter-statement%E2%80%99-rocks-sa|archivedate=17 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} While still the ANCYL leader, Malema was taken to the [[Promotion of Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act, 2000|Equality Court]] by [[AfriForum]] for repeatedly singing “dubul’ ibhunu”, which translate as “shoot the boer [white farmer]”. The ANC supported Malema, though AfriForum and the ANC reached a settlement before the appeal case was due to be argued in the [[Supreme Court of Appeal of South Africa|Supreme Court of Appeal]]. In January 2018, EFF Deputy President [[Floyd Shivambu]] congratulated the Fighters for causing damage to various [[H&M]] stores{{cite tweet |user=FloydShivambu |number=952114009448304640 |date=13 Jan 2018 |title=That @hm nonsense of a clothing store is now facing consequences for its racism. }} across South Africa due to a picture of a young Black child wearing a green hoodie reading, "Coolest Monkey in the Jungle."{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/h-m-the-weeknd-coolest-monkey-in-the-jungle-racist-hoodie/|title=H&M monkey hoodie sparks outrage for "racist" image -
